awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: X-rays, 3D animation and human locomotion
awd_abstract_narration:
Walking efficiently on two legs (bipedalism) is considered a defining characteristic of modern humans, and researchers have long strived to understand how, when, and why human bipedalism evolved. The discoveries of fossilized footprints made by living, moving individuals offer a promising source of data on hominin locomotion to complement what can be learned from fossilized skeletal remains. In this study, X-ray imaging, 3D animation, and computer simulation methods are developed and applied to understand formation of this bipedal record. Such foundational research is required to reconstruct foot anatomy and motion from fossil footprints, and to evaluate competing evolutionary hypotheses about bipedalism. The project represents an interdisciplinary collaboration between primarily undergraduate and major research institutions, with substantial training opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students. Student recruitment will focus on groups historically underrepresented in STEM fields. Results will be translated into pedagogical materials focused on the intersection of science and visual art, and the public will be engaged through museum and media science outreach.

Previous studies have developed methods for interpreting aspects of foot anatomy and motion from human footprints, but none have approached the problem mechanistically to understand the complex foot-substrate interactions through which footprints are formed. Direct observation of these interactions has not been possible because human feet and deformable substrates are both opaque, and contact areas are therefore hidden when a foot sinks to form a footprint. Here, biplanar X-ray, 3D animation, and computer simulation methods will be developed to visualize and analyze movement as individuals walk through substrates to create footprints. Direct mechanistic knowledge of foot-substrate interactions is potentially transformative for paleoanthropologists to extract anatomical and functional inferences from fossil human footprints and use these to test evolutionary hypotheses. Further, new imaging and analysis techniques are readily transferrable to other organisms, and may transform other approaches across animal biomechanics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The practice of habitual bipedal locomotion (i.e., walking upright on two legs) is a defining feature of modern humans that distinguishes us from our living great ape relatives. Paleoanthropologists have long sought to understand when, where, why, and how our peculiar manner of locomotion evolved, given the impacts that bipedalism would have had on many other facets of human evolution. Historically, it has been most common to study locomotion in fossil hominins by examining the morphologies of their bones, but methods for interpreting locomotor behaviors from bony morphology remain controversial. Fossil footprints offer alternative or complementary data, as they represent direct snapshots of extinct hominins moving across their landscapes at moments in time. However, our limited understanding of how to interpret locomotor behaviors from footprint morphology has remained a major obstacle.

Our collaborative project sought to address fundamental questions about the mechanistic process through which footprints form, in order to develop new approaches for interpreting locomotor patterns from them. Doing so would allow us to unlock new data that can address long-standing questions about the evolution of human anatomy and locomotion. We developed and refined new techniques for using biplanar X-ray video (synchronous recording from two overlapping X-ray beams) and 3-D animation to visualize and analyze how human feet function when walking on, and creating footprints in, deformable substrates (Hatala et al., 2018, 2021). We developed and implemented computer simulation methods, which allowed us to understand how substrates responded to foot motion in order to generate a footprint’s final shape. The combination of data from live experiments and from simulations allowed us to break down the mechanical process of footprint formation at an unparalleled level of detail (Hatala et al., 2021). By applying this mechanistic approach, we found that decades-old approaches for directly inferring foot anatomy from fossil footprints were incorrect. Instead, we found that specific aspects of footprint morphology are produced by foot kinematics, recording the pattern by which the foot moved through the deformable substrate. We turned to the human fossil record and found that the famous ~3.66 million-year-old fossil hominin footprints from Laetoli, Tanzania indicate a pattern of foot motion significantly different from that seen in modern humans. Meanwhile, certain ~1.5 million-year-old footprints from Ileret, Kenya indicate a modern human-like pattern, suggesting that perhaps Homo erectus moved in essentially the same way that we do today (Hatala et al., 2023a). In our ongoing work we continue to apply these mechanistic approaches, and we have recently found that perhaps other hominins living alongside Homo erectus used different patterns of bipedal locomotion, which could have impacted their evolution in myriad ways (Hatala et al., 2023b).

Beyond our immediate results, this project led to the development and publication of new methods that can impact fields well beyond anthropology. The techniques that we have introduced for studying locomotion on soft substrates can be applied in diverse areas including but not limited to comparative biology, engineering, and robotics. In each of these fields, methodological limitations have impeded the study of human, other animal, or robotic locomotion on naturalistic terrain. The toolkits that we have developed and published for studying human foot anatomy and biomechanics (e.g., longitudinal arch anatomy and function) can also be used in areas related to human health.

At the core of this project was a rich undergraduate training collaboration between a primarily undergraduate institution (Chatham University) and a major research university (Brown University). A total of seven Chatham undergraduates, all from groups historically underrepresented in STEM, were trained over the five years of this project. Each summer, students received laboratory training at Chatham to learn analytical methods related to the project. Students then traveled with the PI to Brown, where they assisted with biplanar X-ray experiments and participated in laboratory tours and meetings focused on the pursuit of graduate studies and careers in STEM. Several students engaged in research throughout the academic year that followed, pursuing thesis projects that were derived from this one. Two Chatham trainees gave award-winning research presentations at national academic conferences. Two Brown undergraduate students were also trained and pursued independent research linked to this project. Finally, data from the project were translated to pedagogical materials for a joint Brown/Rhode Island School of Design course on Virtual Reality Design.

PI Hatala continues to disseminate results from this project to the public. This has included two virtual public lectures hosted by the Smithsonian National Museum of Natural History and by the Leakey Foundation. This has also occurred through ongoing collaborations with scientists and exhibits staff at the National Museums of Kenya (NMK), who are developing a community-led museum focused on fossil footprints, adjacent to ~1.5 million-year-old footprint sites at Ileret, Kenya. PI Hatala has given lectures and helped to develop exhibits and educational materials, in collaboration with NMK scientists and staff and local community members.
